BALTIMORE, MD., OCTOBER 17. 1922

THE ROOTING SECTION
Now that the season-ticket sale is at end and the reserved-seat section has been mapped out, it seems perfectly possible that the rooting
section might be removed to a more favorable position.
The section now reserved is desirable as a point of observation
over the length of the field, but as a rooting stand it is entirely too open.
The stand, having no solid back, offers no sounding board at all for the
mass cheering.
It would seem advisable to reserve two hundred and fifty seats in
front of the press-box for the rooting section, so that the solid background can throw out the verbal effects where they will be most effective.
We recommend that the head cheer-leader sees Mr. Keyes as to this
arrangement.

Journalism, as a means of livelihood, has claimed a very large percentage of Johns Hopkins graduates of the past few years. Of the number who have entered this field few realized in their undergraduate
days that they would ever enter upon, such a career. Consequently, few
had the advantage of experience in college journalism.
There are at least a half dozen former staff members of THE NEWSLETTER now engaged in newspaper work in this city. These men have
all found themselves at a great advantage over their inexperienced
brother cub reporters.
We take great pleasure in publishing a letter received from one
of these "inexperienced brothers."

To the Editor of the News-Letter:
During the past summer I worked as ,a newspaper reporter on one of the Baltimore papers. Although I made a successful one, due to lack of experience in just the newspaper style, it was some
weeks before my articles began to appear as I had
written them. From the. standpoint of one's outof-college life, it is well to urge the Freshman to
work for the News-Letter, and the editor's statement,"The News-Letter offers the Freshman more
for his time than any other activity," is no idle
boast.
When I went to the city editor of the paper for
which I worked and asked for a job at the beginning of the summer he asked me if I had been on the
News-Letter staff. Although I got the job on my
scholastic record, I could have gotten more money
if I had been a member of the News-Letter staff.
Finally, the question of the city editor should
to all Hopkins men. Our paper is
gratifying
be
recognized on the outside as a creditable newspaper and one on which the student can get real newspaper experience. Freshmen, here is your chance.
ALBERT G. LANGELUTTIG,JR.,
Graduate Student.

INTERNATIONAL STUDENT CONTEST FOR BEST ESSAY ON
PROHIBITION

NOTED SPEAKERS PROCURED BY Y. M. C. A.
Professor A. F. Foster, scientific
theologian, and Mr. Samuel Schumacher, student Episcopal clergyman at Princeton University,
have accepted invitations to come
to Hopkins and address the students in the near future. Both
visits will be under the auspices
of the Y. M. C. A.
Professor Foster will be at the
university on October 23 and 24.
He is a Baltimorean, having atMarstons
tended
University
School before taking up the study
of theology. He will meet the students in an informal way and discuss with them theological questions from a scientific point of
view. He will encourage the asking of questions that the students
do not clearly understand so that
they will comprehend his religiou3
ideas.
Mr. Schumacher will address
the assembly on November 2 and
his remarks will center around
the general problems of student
life. Mr. Schumacher was a
prominent preacher at the Silver
Bay Students' Conference on Lake
George during the past summer.
He has also done missionary work
in China.
The visits of these clergymen
will be the inauguration of a policy of the local Y. M. C. A. to bring
men of prominence to Hopkins to
give the students instruction in
vital questions with which they
are intimately concerned. The
names of other speakers who will
appear early in the winter will be
announced shortly.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, OCTOBER 17, 1922.
DR. FRENCH TO ADDRESS
ZIONIST MEETING
The Johns Hopkins Zionist Society will begin its work this year
by holding its first meeting at
12.30 Friday, October 20, at 110
M. E. Hall. Dr. French will be
the principal speaker.
The Zionist Society, through its
lectures and study circles, aims to
study conditions existing in Palestine. It also discusses plans and
measures proposed for the rebuilding of Palestine. The Zionist Society also takes interest in the social life of its members, giving
several social affairs during the
course of the academic year.
Recent events in world history
have stressed the important role
which Palestine plays in the affairs of the Near-East. The ratification of the Palestine mandate
by the Council of the League of
Nations and by the United States
Senate has almost assured the political status of Palestine. Efforts
are being made to introduce modern industrial methods, and to
better the living conditions for all
the inhabitants.
All students interested are invited to be present at this organization meeting.
CROSS-COUNTRY PROSPECTS
The Cross-Country Team is
practicing four times weekly on
the University course. Three
members of last year's team who
are showing the best form are
Holsapple, Somerville and Verne
Booth. These men can be expected to carry the team through
the season successfully.
Of last year's squad Fenton,
Cronin and Leytz are showing
good -fotin and with sume- experience will undoubtedly show great
improvement. New men out for
the team are Huey, Bentenkoff,
Childs, Manahan, "Wasson, KinWillson,
Wickham,
namon,
Houghton and a few others. Of
these Huey, of last year's lacrosse
team, shows the most promise.
The new course is expected to
be ready this week. It will be a
great improvement.
Manager Shriver has tentatively arranged a dual meet with the
University of Maryland. The
championship meets which the
University will engage in are the
Middle Atlantics, on November
26, and the South Atlantics, on or
about Thanksgiving.

TENTATIVE COTILLON
DATES SET
The three dances which are to
be given this year under the auspices of the Cotillon Board will
be held at the dance hall of the
Maryland Casualty Building. One
of the best orchestras in the city
has been obtained and the board
expects both the decorations and
refreshments to be better than
they have formerly been. The
tentative dates for the cotillons
are: December 21, February 21
and April 6.
The Cotillon Board has also announced that dances will be given
after all the football games in the
Civil Engineering Building. The
music will be supplied by the already famous Blue Jay Seven. All
are cordially invited to attend.
R. 0. T. C. HOLDS FIRST
DRILL
With a display of neat khaki
uniforms, shouts of "tenshun,"
"ri, face," etc., and a general show
of militaristic efficiency the R. 0.
T. C. held its first drill of the 192223 season last ,Monday, the ninth.
Some of the troops busily engaged themselves blowing their
respective horns with the Band in
the Barn. The remaining future
generals held drilling practice on
the upper quadrangle. The 265 enrolled men were divided into four
sections, each led and instructed
by veteran officers.

Board held last Wednesday, Eben
Perkins was appointed to take
charge of a group of Freshmen
who will place in prominent
places throughout the city posters
for all Hopkins football games.

LL over the country the whistle is blowing for
the kick-off, the start of that great game—
another college year.
Be on your toes when the whistle blows. A good
start will carry you well on toward your goal.
Let the football candidate start by working
away till his muscles ache from bucking the line.
Let the aspirant for manager put in careful
study of his team's needs, always eager to help
—arranging a trip or carrying a pail of water.
Let the publications man be alert for news and
tireless in learning the details of editorial work.
Whatever activity you come out for, crowd a
lot of energy into these early Fall days.
And if a good start helps win campus honors,
it helps win class room honors, too. The sure way
to be up in your work is to aim now for regularity
at lectures, up-to-date note-books and particular
attention to the early chapters of text-books,thus
getting a grip on the basics.
This is best in the long run, and—selfishly--it is
easiest in the long run. That is, iflife after college is
made easier by the things a bigger income can buy.

BALTIMORE, MD., OCTOBER 17. 1922

THE ROOTING SECTION
Now that the season-ticket sale is at end and the reserved-seat section has been mapped out, it seems perfectly possible that the rooting
section might be removed to a more favorable position.
The section now reserved is desirable as a point of observation
over the length of the field, but as a rooting stand it is entirely too open.
The stand, having no solid back, offers no sounding board at all for the
mass cheering.
It would seem advisable to reserve two hundred and fifty seats in
front of the press-box for the rooting section, so that the solid background can throw out the verbal effects where they will be most effective.
We recommend that the head cheer-leader sees Mr. Keyes as to this
arrangement.

Journalism, as a means of livelihood, has claimed a very large percentage of Johns Hopkins graduates of the past few years. Of the number who have entered this field few realized in their undergraduate
days that they would ever enter upon, such a career. Consequently, few
had the advantage of experience in college journalism.
There are at least a half dozen former staff members of THE NEWSLETTER now engaged in newspaper work in this city. These men have
all found themselves at a great advantage over their inexperienced
brother cub reporters.
We take great pleasure in publishing a letter received from one
of these "inexperienced brothers."

To the Editor of the News-Letter:
During the past summer I worked as ,a newspaper reporter on one of the Baltimore papers. Although I made a successful one, due to lack of experience in just the newspaper style, it was some
weeks before my articles began to appear as I had
written them. From the. standpoint of one's outof-college life, it is well to urge the Freshman to
work for the News-Letter, and the editor's statement,"The News-Letter offers the Freshman more
for his time than any other activity," is no idle
boast.
When I went to the city editor of the paper for
which I worked and asked for a job at the beginning of the summer he asked me if I had been on the
News-Letter staff. Although I got the job on my
scholastic record, I could have gotten more money
if I had been a member of the News-Letter staff.
Finally, the question of the city editor should
to all Hopkins men. Our paper is
gratifying

INTERNATIONAL STUDENT CONTEST FOR BEST ESSAY ON
PROHIBITION

NOTED SPEAKERS PROCURED BY Y. M. C. A.
Professor A. F. Foster, scientific
theologian, and Mr. Samuel Schumacher, student Episcopal clergyman at Princeton University,
have accepted invitations to come
to Hopkins and address the students in the near future. Both
visits will be under the auspices
of the Y. M. C. A.
Professor Foster will be at the
university on October 23 and 24.
He is a Baltimorean, having atMarstons
tended
University
School before taking up the study
of theology. He will meet the students in an informal way and discuss with them theological questions from a scientific point of
view. He will encourage the asking of questions that the students
do not clearly understand so that
they will comprehend his religiou3
ideas.
Mr. Schumacher will address
the assembly on November 2 and
his remarks will center around
the general problems of student
life. Mr. Schumacher was a
prominent preacher at the Silver
Bay Students' Conference on Lake
George during the past summer.
He has also done missionary work
in China.
The visits of these clergymen
will be the inauguration of a policy of the local Y. M. C. A. to bring
men of prominence to Hopkins to
give the students instruction in
vital questions with which they
are intimately concerned. The
names of other speakers who will
appear early in the winter will be
announced shortly.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, OCTOBER 17, 1922.
DR. FRENCH TO ADDRESS
ZIONIST MEETING
The Johns Hopkins Zionist Society will begin its work this year
by holding its first meeting at
12.30 Friday, October 20, at 110
M. E. Hall. Dr. French will be
the principal speaker.
The Zionist Society, through its
lectures and study circles, aims to
study conditions existing in Palestine. It also discusses plans and
measures proposed for the rebuilding of Palestine. The Zionist Society also takes interest in the social life of its members, giving
several social affairs during the
course of the academic year.
Recent events in world history
have stressed the important role
which Palestine plays in the affairs of the Near-East. The ratification of the Palestine mandate
by the Council of the League of
Nations and by the United States
Senate has almost assured the political status of Palestine. Efforts
are being made to introduce modern industrial methods, and to
better the living conditions for all
the inhabitants.
All students interested are invited to be present at this organization meeting.
CROSS-COUNTRY PROSPECTS
The Cross-Country Team is
practicing four times weekly on
the University course. Three
members of last year's team who
are showing the best form are
Holsapple, Somerville and Verne
Booth. These men can be expected to carry the team through
the season successfully.
Of last year's squad Fenton,
Cronin and Leytz are showing
good -fotin and with sume- experience will undoubtedly show great
improvement. New men out for
the team are Huey, Bentenkoff,
Childs, Manahan, "Wasson, KinWillson,
Wickham,
namon,
Houghton and a few others. Of
these Huey, of last year's lacrosse
team, shows the most promise.
The new course is expected to
be ready this week. It will be a
great improvement.
Manager Shriver has tentatively arranged a dual meet with the
University of Maryland. The
championship meets which the
University will engage in are the
Middle Atlantics, on November
26, and the South Atlantics, on or
about Thanksgiving.

TENTATIVE COTILLON
DATES SET
The three dances which are to
be given this year under the auspices of the Cotillon Board will
be held at the dance hall of the
Maryland Casualty Building. One
of the best orchestras in the city
has been obtained and the board
expects both the decorations and
refreshments to be better than
they have formerly been. The
tentative dates for the cotillons
are: December 21, February 21
and April 6.
The Cotillon Board has also announced that dances will be given
after all the football games in the
Civil Engineering Building. The
music will be supplied by the already famous Blue Jay Seven. All
are cordially invited to attend.
R. 0. T. C. HOLDS FIRST
DRILL
With a display of neat khaki
uniforms, shouts of "tenshun,"
"ri, face," etc., and a general show
of militaristic efficiency the R. 0.
T. C. held its first drill of the 192223 season last ,Monday, the ninth.
Some of the troops busily engaged themselves blowing their
respective horns with the Band in
the Barn. The remaining future
generals held drilling practice on
the upper quadrangle. The 265 enrolled men were divided into four
sections, each led and instructed
by veteran officers.

It will pay you to

LL over the country the whistle is blowing for
the kick-off, the start of that great game—
another college year.
Be on your toes when the whistle blows. A good
start will carry you well on toward your goal.
Let the football candidate start by working
away till his muscles ache from bucking the line.
Let the aspirant for manager put in careful
study of his team's needs, always eager to help
—arranging a trip or carrying a pail of water.
Let the publications man be alert for news and
tireless in learning the details of editorial work.
Whatever activity you come out for, crowd a
lot of energy into these early Fall days.
And if a good start helps win campus honors,
it helps win class room honors, too. The sure way
to be up in your work is to aim now for regularity
at lectures, up-to-date note-books and particular
attention to the early chapters of text-books,thus
getting a grip on the basics.
This is best in the long run, and—selfishly--it is
easiest in the long run. That is, iflife after college is
made easier by the things a bigger income can buy.
